docs.snippet: AUBUSSON-Chrystian. The longtime French antiques dealer, Chrystian Count Aubusson de Cavarlay, passed away January 29, at the age of 82 in his Easthampton home. He was a much beloved and esteemed Manhattan antiques dealer who maintained his shop, ...
docs.lead_paragraph: AUBUSSON-Chrystian. The longtime French antiques dealer, Chrystian Count Aubusson de Cavarlay, passed away January 29, at the age of 82 in his Easthampton home. He was a much beloved and esteemed Manhattan antiques dealer who maintained his shop, Chrystian Aubusson Antiques, starting in New York shortly after his arrival from his native France after WWII, until his retirement in 2001. His wit and wisdom, elegance and good humor will be dearly missed by all those fortunate enough to know him. His many kindnesses will be well remembered. Daniel Barney, Daniel Barney Antiques Charles Kriz, Stewart Schreiber, Old Versailles Inc Roger Gross, George Rodriguez, Victor Alonzo, Objets Plus Inc Ben and Marie Claude Passalacqua, Paris Antiques Alberto de Caro, Enrique Rodriguez Hidalgo, Circea Antiques Hubert des Forges, Oscar Moore, Hubert des Forges Inc

docs.snippet: For her concert at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday afternoon, Felicity Lott sidestepped the conventions of the vocal recital format and offered a program that was refreshingly jumbled, yet also thematically unified. Instead of groups by individual or l...
docs.lead_paragraph: For her concert at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday afternoon, Felicity Lott sidestepped the conventions of the vocal recital format and offered a program that was refreshingly jumbled, yet also thematically unified. Instead of groups by individual or like-minded composers, Dame Felicity presented each half of the program as a unified set. Composers who worked in different languages and musical styles were heard side by side with no applause between them at Dame Felicity's request. She gave her program a title, ''Night and Day: Love Songs Round the Clock,'' and that was what she offered: there were 24 songs all told, and if they didn't match the hours exactly, the pieces she sang on the first half were set in the morning and afternoon, and those in the second half were more decisively nocturnal. She mostly drew from the formal art song repertory. But she ended the first half with Oscar Straus's cabaret song, ''Warum soll eine Frau kein Verhältnis haben?'' (''Why shouldn't a woman have an affair?''), and she closed the program with the Cole Porter song that gave her recital its title.
docs.abstract: Allan Kozinn reviews Felicity Lott's vocal recital at Alice Tully Hall (S)

headline.main: With a Nod to Cole Porter, Songs for Night and Day

docs.snippet: In the opening credits for ''The Hours,'' a drama about three women from different eras whose lives are connected by a shared despair and by a work of literature, the names of the film's stars appear in the following order: Meryl Streep, Julianne ...
docs.lead_paragraph: In the opening credits for ''The Hours,'' a drama about three women from different eras whose lives are connected by a shared despair and by a work of literature, the names of the film's stars appear in the following order: Meryl Streep, Julianne Moore, Nicole Kidman. A stopwatch taken to the film shows that the actresses appear fairly equally: Ms. Streep for 42 minutes, Ms. Moore for 33 and Ms. Kidman for about 30. And yet the studios that co-produced the film, Paramount and Miramax, are pushing Ms. Streep and Ms. Kidman for a best actress Oscar and Ms. Moore, at her request, for best supporting actress.
docs.abstract: Jockeying for Academy Awards this year again raises question of what constitutes lead role versus supporting role; Catherine Zeta-Jones, Julianne Moore, and Alfred Molina are being pushed for nominations as supporting performers despite considerable screen time they have in their respective films: Chicago, The Hours and Frida; studios usually bow to wishes of performers and their agents when it comes to waging Oscar campaign, but certain amount of arm twisting is sometimes applied if executives fear that star egos are threatening a movie's eventual Oscar tally, which can mean millions of dollars in revenue; photos (M)

headline.main: No. 2 Spot Or the Star? For Oscars, It's Strategy

docs.snippet: On the frontispiece of ''The Quiet American,'' Graham Greene quotes another well-traveled skeptic, Lord Byron: ''This is the patent age of new inventions/ For killing bodies, and for saving souls,/ All propagated with the best intentions.''     In...
docs.lead_paragraph: On the frontispiece of ''The Quiet American,'' Graham Greene quotes another well-traveled skeptic, Lord Byron: ''This is the patent age of new inventions/ For killing bodies, and for saving souls,/ All propagated with the best intentions.'' In novels, screenplays and short stories, Greene chronicled the end of empire. Scorning those who stood in history's way, he did not spare heroes, patriots or the naïve. ''God save us always from the innocent and the good,'' Fowler, the jaded correspondent who narrates ''The Quiet American,'' says to the French inspector, Vigot. After critics called Greene anti-American, Hollywood distorted ''The Quiet American'' in 1958 with a heroically happy ending. After the Sept. 11 attacks, Miramax postponed the second film version until Sir Michael Caine, who portrays Fowler, became persuasively unquiet. (It opened last November.)
docs.abstract: Martin F Nolan article on The Quiet American, Graham Greene novel set in Vietnam in 1952, and its two screen adaptations, a 1958 Hollywood version that distorted book and deeply offended Greene and current one in which Sir Michael Caine, as disaffected British journalist, restores book's anti-American edge; photo (M)

headline.main: Graham Greene's Unquiet Novel; On Film and in Print, 'The Quiet American' Still Fascinates

docs.snippet: The vengeful, bewitching heroine of ''Chaos'' goes by two names, Malika and Noémie. But as embodied by Rachida Brakni, who won a César (the French equivalent of an Oscar) last year as the most promising actress, she is indelible either way. Agai...
docs.lead_paragraph: The vengeful, bewitching heroine of ''Chaos'' goes by two names, Malika and Noémie. But as embodied by Rachida Brakni, who won a César (the French equivalent of an Oscar) last year as the most promising actress, she is indelible either way. Against all odds this beautiful, street-smart survivor of countless rapes and assaults at the hands of a gang that enslaved her and forced her to work the streets of Paris as a prostitute has retained her fighting spirit, and sex is her weapon. When she aims her fiery gaze into a man's eyes, he's a goner. A witchy, saucer-eyed waif with ivory skin and a head full of gleaming ebony tendrils, Malika proudly calls that gaze -- a calculated blend of beseeching vulnerability and smoldering heat -- the ''flamethrower.'' Directed at unsuspecting targets like Paul (Vincent Lindon) and Fabrice (Aurélien Wiik), a spoiled Parisian father and son, both itching for a comeuppance, she reduces them to quivering, cow-eyed fools.
docs.abstract: Stephen Holden reviews Coline Serreau film Chaos; photo (M)

headline.main: Sexist Pigs Skewered Over a Flamethrower

docs.snippet: A retired Miami police officer testifying as a prosecution witness in the federal corruption trial of 11 former Miami officers said today that he never saw them plant guns at crime scenes, as they are accused of doing, but that it was a commonly k...
docs.lead_paragraph: A retired Miami police officer testifying as a prosecution witness in the federal corruption trial of 11 former Miami officers said today that he never saw them plant guns at crime scenes, as they are accused of doing, but that it was a commonly known practice. ''It was like it was a common-knowledge thing,'' the retired officer, William Hames, testified. ''It was joked about. It was something you heard.''
docs.abstract: William Hames, retired Miami police officer, testifies as prosecution witness in federal corruption trial of 11 former Miami officers; says that he never saw them plant guns at crime scenes, as they are accused of doing, but that it was commonly known practice; says he has firsthand knowledge that some of officers conspired to lie about their actions in deadly shooting in 1995; defendants' lawyers call their clients scapegoats who practiced aggressive police work to protect citizens in crime-ridden neighborhoods; attack Hames's credibility and note his history of drinking on the job; Hames is one of two former officers who pleaded guilty to conspiracy charges last year related to one of questionable shootings, agreeing to plea deal in hopes of receiving reduced sentence; photo (M)

headline.main: Ex-Miami Officer Testifies In Police Corruption Case

docs.snippet: We get tremory    In this world with no memory    Life makes only partial sense    Knowing only the present tense.      You might have thought that ''On the Electrodynamics of Moving Bodies,'' the 1905 paper in which Albert Einstein proposed the t...
docs.lead_paragraph: We get tremory In this world with no memory Life makes only partial sense Knowing only the present tense. You might have thought that ''On the Electrodynamics of Moving Bodies,'' the 1905 paper in which Albert Einstein proposed the theory of relativity, would be an unlikely subject for song and dance. After all, haven't art and science been at war since the British scientist and novelist C. P. Snow said so in a famous 1959 lecture, ''The Two Cultures''?
docs.abstract: Comment on recent spate of films and plays that deal with science or scientists; photo (M)

headline.main: Lab Coat Chic: The Arts Embrace Science

docs.lead_paragraph: DORIAN An Imitation By Will Self 278 pages. Grove Press. $24. Oscar Wilde's ''Picture of Dorian Gray'' was a sly, witty response to the aestheticism that flourished in England in the 1880's: a cautionary tale about the relationship between life and art and about the dangers of confusing the two.
docs.abstract: Michiko Kakutani reviews Will Self book Dorian: An Imitation; photo (M)
